trial_identification.studytitle: Promotion of healthy aging in Northern Tasmania: the benefits to older adults of resistance training
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effects of resistance training versus flexibility training on cognitive function, quality of life and mood, muscular control and fitness, and cardiovascular function in older adults: a randomized crossover trial

conditions.healthcondition: Psychological and physiological intermediates for cerebrovascular and cardiovascular disease

interventions.interventions: Subjects undergo 2 exercise periods of 4 months each with order allocated at random: a) resistance training based on the living Longer Living Stronger Program (Council of Ageing Tasmania) with 2 supervised gym and 1 unsupervised home session per week; b) flexibility training with 2 supervised gym and 1 unsupervised home session per week. Each session will last 30-60 minutes

primaryOutcome.outcome: a) cognitive function, quality of life and mood assessment
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at start, 2 months and 4 months

primaryOutcome.outcome: b) muscle strength and cardiovascular fitness
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at start, 2 months and 4 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: a) Blood pressure and vascular compliance
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Each measured at start, 2 months and 4 months.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Willing to undertake an exercise program in the Launceston and North-west Coast regions of Tasmania.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pre-existing symptomatic cerebrovascular, cardiovascular disease or dementia, diabetes or hypertension.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation following recruitment, concealed by blinded list held by investigator independent of participant or research officer
